Posts.Content: My husband now has an inguinal lump while still having a fairly low psa. Are we facing a met? Can you please direct me to an appropriate thread?
Posts.Signature: Deech Husband 68 y.o., Father had PCa Local urologist DRE revealed no lumps/bumps PSA May/2012 2.97 PSA Aug 2013 3.91 PSA May 2014 3.1 PSA May 6, 2015 8.5 PSA May 20, 2015 12.9 Prostate Needle Core Biopsy Highlights June 2015: Right mid: low grade adenocarcinoma, Gleason 3+3 = 6, present in 1 of 2 core biopsies, occupying 1% of 1 core left apex: low grade adenocarcinoma, Gleason 3+3 = 6, present in 1 of several cores, occupying 10% of 1 core Stage T1C Weight of prostate 55g CT negative Bone Scan Negative PSA July 17, 2015 7.0 note: after antibiotics x 10 days (no surgery in interim)
Posts.Title: Inguinal lump after 2-3 years of watchful waiting

Posts.Content: Good Morning, My husband's urologist/surgeon is urging surgery/RT sooner than later in my husband's case. His urologist has gone on vacation for two weeks, and in the meantime, husband plans to start a two week course of antibiotics hoping to lower his PSA. He asked the urologist about it in an email but didn't get an answer. Husband is assuming urologist didn't order antibiotics because on DRE there was no tenderness or mushiness and no lumps/bumps. But I'm wondering what is accomplished if he lowers his PSA at this point? I suspect it's a measure of denial at work but I surely do not know. (I hesitate to ask him directly because 1) he IS a medical professional and 2) I don't want to sound like I'm challenging his professional opinion. ) The urologist has already said, "...if PSA is rising due to more aggressive cancer, then we are in the window period of treatment that could affect a cure. If we wait and the PSA goes to 20 or 25, we may be too late." As you can see in my signature, it is rising rather quickly. He (my husband, not the urologist) is also opining that a second opinion for his stats is not warranted. If anyone has thoughts on that, I would appreciate any comments. Thank you for any thoughts. I appreciate what I've learned from all of you; I've spent hours reading on this forum.
Posts.Signature: Deech Husband 68 y.o., Father had PCa Local urologist DRE revealed no lumps/bumps PSA May/2012 2.97 PSA Aug 2013 3.91 PSA May 2014 3.1 PSA May 6, 2015 8.5 PSA May 20, 2015 12.9 Prostate Needle Core Biopsy Highlights June 2015: Right mid: low grade adenocarcinoma, Gleason 3+3 = 6, present in 1 of 2 core biopsies, occupying 1% of 1 core left apex: low grade adenocarcinoma, Gleason 3+3 = 6, present in 1 of several cores, occupying 10% of 1 core Stage T1C Weight of prostate 55g CT negative Bone Scan Negative PSA July 17, 2015 7.0 note: after antibiotics x 10 days (no surgery in interim)
Posts.Title: Antibiotics and Second Opinion before Surgery

Posts.Content: I appreciate so many responses... Getting responses, I found, also makes the whole situation more real. I'm taking the advice to breathe. Hubby read the responses we received yesterday and appreciates all of them. There is still so much I didn't know and he did explain some to me. We have the Walsh book but have only glanced through it. We are just getting back to normal after 2 weeks with our grandchildren. My mind was distracted from all of this, in a good way. It's time to read and make calls and pray for wisdom. I need to correct a misunderstanding though. My hubby (Not the urologist) is the one who thinks a second opinion isn't necessary because of his relatively low numbers. I edited my info just now to reconcile the ambiguity. So much more to learn. Be sure more questions are on the way! Thank you for being here.
